topic.title: IPFS youtube uploader using python
topic.body:
After seeing 99fk's thread about a tool for downloading youtube videos and uploading them to IPFS (found here http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1563400508_1E1ETHw8wzWhza7R49wyrM1U9ZRHvykejr/YouTube+to+IPFS ) I felt inspired to make my own tool that does the exact same thing. 
It uses python 3 and can be found here https://github.com/qspitzer/Python-Youtube-to-IPFS

topic.title: Could the shutdown of 8chan be helping zeronet grow?
topic.body:
Now I know that the 8chan shutdown has caused ZN to grow, but do you think that it will also get non-8chan users to join as well? My thought process is that:

1) With 8chan shutdown, users have started to use ZN
2) The increased usage of ZN by former 8chan users has caused MSM to start reporting. 
3) More people will hear about ZN and try it out to see if it is as bad as MSM is reporting.

topic.title: Resetting Lenovo Thinkpad L450 BIOS supervisor password?
topic.body: I am having trouble resetting the supervisor password on my lenovo l450. I got the laptop used, and I need to set the date which can only be done after the supervisor password has been entered. I am trying to reset it with the short-circuit method, but I cannot get my changes to stick. I am following this guide (https://www.reddit.com/r/thinkpad/comments/4z9czz/resetting_the_eepromlost_supervisor_password_on/) and I am able to get into the bios, but my changes do not stick after rebooting. Does anyone have any experience with this sort of thing and willing to point me in the right direction?

topic.title: Did youtube block tor?
topic.body: Is anyone able to use youtube with Tor? The site loads for me, but all of the videos and titles are grayed out. I remember that youtube [temporarily went down](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1557922831_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm) for Tor users at one point, but is it now down permanently?

1561066486_1HiSNH8Uh5LSRjqxtrZrBUEquny9D.body: If you are unable to get the VeraCrypt hidden OS to work, you could create an encrypted VM instead. It won't be as fast, and it won't be hidden (but it won't be as obvious it is there), but it should work with most computers

> [insurgo](#comment_30_18UFtLHDzWDN1um1NphCGuTW4QnTsBaNH2): https://tails.boum.org/ [...]

https://www.digi77.com/linux-kodachi/
Kodachi seems like it has more security and anonymizing features than TAILS, so it might be a better choice

https://www.supremecourt.ohio.gov/rod/docs/pdf/0/2009/2009-Ohio-6426.pdf

Assuming that your school is in the US, the school should not be able to search your laptop without your permission. In State v. Smith,124 Ohio St. 3d 163, 2009-Ohio-6426, the court ruled that, because of the 4th amendment, cellphones may not be searched without a warrant (unless there is probable cause). The court deemed that cellphones were similar to laptops, which require a warrant to search (unless there is probable cause). So if your boarding school is based in the US, then the school should not be allowed to search your laptop without permission.

> [slamon](#comment_7_1PNJZzvokVc1fVcA3U6hXfRPSZLcEfYJAc): It's still worth hiding stuff.

I agree, but if it is not possible using encryption and a hidden OS like the OP wants to do, then then not showing your data could be a solution, at least partially

> [sunflowerr](#comment_4_1HiSNH8Uh5LSRjqxtrZrBUEquny9DNwzxZ): Actually it's in the UK. Does that change something?

https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/674416/Searching_screening_and_confiscation.pdf

It seems like the same sort of thing applies to the UK. The school should not be able to search electronic devices without your permission, unless there is reason to believe that it is being used to break the law. You might want to do some further research to confirm my claim, but it seems like you don't need to show your data to the school if you don't want to (assuming you aren't breaking the law)

> [pineapples](#comment_36_19XCfah7iuo9zYqk7GoTDXVNp4p5BpEH1T): a private boarding school has every right to search their student's possessions, even electronic files, because they are not part of the government.  The school can have a policy that states that every student that attends must let the teachers or whoever search their belongings upon request.  If the student does not comply then the school will kick them out.

Not entirely. In the US, if the school receives any federal funding, it must follow federal law. So while some private schools can search without violating the 4th amendment, not all of them can

https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/463220/Guide_to_Children_s_Home_Standards_inc_quality_standards_Version__1.17_FINAL.pdf

You could argue that the searching of your computer with no probable cause removes your reasonable privacy, which would violate part 3.36: "Observation, monitoring or surveillance of children must not remove reasonable privacy, and should allow as much privacy as is possible, including in dressing, washing and using the toilet. A record must be kept of all observations in bedrooms to ensure that children are not subject to unnecessary invasions of their privacy."

UK boarding schools are legally children's homes because they house children for 295+ days, which is why they must follow children's home's laws

Try reinstalling the program to fix this problem.Tried 3 different ones,none of them worked.What else should be installed?Or maybe someone has a zip with all the additional .net dll's that are needed to run zeronet?

Did you try restarting the computer? If I am remembering correctly, if windows has an update that it wants to install, some of the DLL's will vanish until the computer is updated. If that doesn't work, then you could try to reinstall the .NET framework

1563542681_189CZFM3FgMFXz6XvoFLNyPW6v5EB.body: As others have mentioned, it will likely be abused. But it will likely be abused by not only the government, but also by the citizens. The problem with "hate speech" is that everyone is different. If you were to say the dreaded "n-word" to a large group of people, some people will consider it hateful, while others don't. Now, lets say that you live in the UK, and you don't like someone. You could just say that that person is saying hateful things to you, and then they will go to jail.

1563588405_1Hc87xHmLsZyaGTQYnx2UmQPKwE1E.body:
> [kai0](#comment_1052_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): make a tool for zeronet, most chinese don't know to use IPFS because it can't run by click mouse. or you can make a app  for runing IPFS by click mouse.

I'm a bit confused by your question. Are you asking about a tool that uploads videos to zeronet, or one that uploads to IPFS from videos on zeronet?

Also, IPFS is about as difficult (and possibly easier) to use as zeronet, so I don't see why Chinese people would have a hard time using it.

> [kai0](#comment_1053_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): running IPFS need command not like zeronet just click mouse, that's why most chinese don't know how to use. if you can make a app for running IPFS just click mouse then most people know how to use it.you also can make a tool for copy video to zeronet site, running zeronet is much easy than running IPFS.

IPFS can be used without installing anything. The site ipfs.io is on IPFS, but you can access it without running anything. ipfs.io also allows access to all of the files on IPFS. Installing IPFS allows the user to upload files and helps speed up the network, but files can be downloaded without installing

> [kai0](#comment_1054_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): how to use IPFS without installing anything?

You can search for files on IPFS with ipfs-search.com and then download them through the cloudflare-ipfs links it provides

1565358483_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac.body:
Well the directors are wrong. Putting a backdoor into encryption will make it pretty much useless. It won't affect most people for a bit, but once one person manages to break the backdoor, they will have broken all of the encryption that uses it. And if that person releases the backdoor key, then everyone will be able to decrypt anything that uses that same backdoor.

As for how it affects ZeroNet, I am not certain. The ZeroNet app will likely not implement the any backdoors (if anyone tries, it can easily be removed by someone else). Online shopping will likely become unsafe because anyone who can decrypt the traffic could then steal credit card details

yep

> [tumbleweed](#comment_1_1HSJXS26WAFxab3etLidavpj5zki3bC1Pm): Every time you post a message on the Zeronet it has to be signed with your private key. So every message you post provides cryptographic proof of your identity. [...]

This seems like a good solution for the time, but IMO implementing a little dot next to the name or something would be better. Posting your public key to verify it is you not only runs the risk of the user accidentally posting their private key, but it also uses storage. Users only have 50K of posting storage by default, and including your public key in every post will cause you to use more storage than necessary

> [tumbleweed](#comment_2_1HSJXS26WAFxab3etLidavpj5zki3bC1Pm): Every time you post a message on Zeronet you post your public key. It's part of your url for that message..ðŸ˜€

ah, I see. I don't know the all in's and out's of how ZeroNet works, but I guess I should have at least guessed that based on the fact that private keys are used

> [styromaniac@kxoid.bit](#comment_101_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8BdnSv3): Anyone who thinks Trump was a triumph in democracy doesn't understand how rigged presidential elections are.

exactly. a majority of the us had voted for hillary, but trump still won in the end

> [styromaniac@kxoid.bit](#comment_102_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8BdnSv3): You're not smart. Emphasis on "rigged." Both national conventions only select what the donor class wants. You don't get a different president except by name and team color. The policies remain the same.

I never said I was smart (also, I was agreeing with you, but whatever.) What I was trying to do (but I guess I failed to do) was to highlight the fact that despite a majority of the US population voting for one candidate, the other one won. If that doesn't scream "rigged" (at least on some level) then I don't know what will.

> [nickwa](#comment_365_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): Boohoo, you did not get the result you want from a select small big cities. Cry me a river.

I mean, I didn't really want either of them. But my point I was trying to make is that even though a majority of the population voted for one candidate, the other one won. The same thing happened with George W Bush, Benjamin Harrison, Rutherford B Hayes, and John Quincy Adams. I just used the Clinton-Trump example because it was the most recent one

1565925621_194xi8BJsLXhwje1kBJETKo6tjvhH.body: There is a good chance that I am wrong (at least in some part), but I do not think that the file is actually uploaded to other computers (again, there is a good chance that I am wrong). What I believe happens is that when you upload a file, X number of announcers are told that you are now seeding your file, which allows others to actually find it. Then, when another user wants to view your file, they download it and then become a seeder as well. (Once again, this is my understanding of what happens. In the very likely case that I have made a mistake, please feel free to correct me)

1567558797_1K5YHnyAFQxWB6x7bnX2yF7D82f34.body:
I believe that it is currently being worked on (but I may be wrong). The benefits are similar to Tor in the sense that both services would provide the user will anonymity. The difference though is that while Tor is slowed down by torrenting (which ZeroNet uses), I2P encourages (and i believe is built for) torrenting because it helps with the everyone's overall anonymity.

One drawback is that ZeroNet might be slower if it switches to I2P. In my experience, I2P has been much slower than Tor, and has also been a bit less reliable (although the websites are all coming from centralized sources, so these might not be issues for ZeroNet)
